text: The next principle we're going to discuss is premium.
Premium is the prices at which sellers aggressively enter the market in order to capture a price
Markets will very quickly move away from premium prices, and often these are depicted with
tails or very aggressive sell-side price action.
Once a market has determined a certain price as premium, the price becomes a pivotal area
for future reference.
So again, just like discounted prices where buyers enter aggressively to pick up
those prices and the advantage, sellers enter when prices enter or enter a premium or an
area known as premium prices.
Now note, the key thing in both discount and premium prices worth mentioning is that the
point at which a price is deemed a discount or premium, in the future that price point
becomes a key pivot point.
And we will discuss this at a later stage when talking about strategy, but this is
something you definitely want to watch out.
The last principle we want to talk about is excess or exuberant prices.
When the auction process extends beyond prices of fair value as well as discount and premium
prices we then enter excess prices or exuberant prices.
The reasoning behind these prices being advertised stem from the psychology behind
buyers and sellers.
And, as such, markets can advertise at prices which would under normal circumstances seem
illogical.
These are deemed excess or exuberant prices.
Whilst these prices can often be reversed relatively fast, timing is essential, as
markets can remain illogical a lot longer than investors remaining liquid.
The key point to note is once a market finds an excess top or bottom, these tend to hold
as highs and lows for longer periods as the market begins a process of balancing and stability.
So note, when you find a market starts to move well beyond what makes logical sense,
it's not that you want to be fighting this, you do not want to stand against
However, once the market does find a turning point, that is where you want to step in with
confidence and go against the trend, because once that market finds that high or low in
exuberant prices, we tend to hold those prices for some months.
Two examples you can look at is when oil spiked up to $136 a barrel back in 2008.
If you go look at the chart you will see how not only was that the top but we very very quickly
navigated away from those exuberant crazy prices. The other example to look at is the gold price
in 2011. Once we peaked up above $1900 a barrel you'll very quickly see how the market
very quickly moved away from that top and as such continued downward. This now concludes
